definition: nine orifices of the human body (eyes, nostrils, ears, mouth, urethra, anus)
hole/opening/orifice (of the human body)/(fig.) key (to the solution of a problem)
hole/opening/orifice (of the human body)/(fig.) key (to the solution of a problem)
the seven apertures of the human head: 2 eyes, 2 ears, 2 nostrils, 1 mouth

(TCM) six bowels (hollow organs), namely: gall bladder 膽|胆[dan3], stomach 胃[wei4], large intestine 大腸|大肠[da4 chang2], small intestine 小腸|小肠[xiao3 chang2], triple heater 三焦[san1 jiao1], bladder 膀胱[pang2 guang1]
five viscera of TCM, namely: heart 心[xin1], liver 肝[gan1], spleen 脾[pi2], lungs 肺[fei4] and kidneys 腎|肾[shen4]
(TCM) the three truncal cavities (thoracic, abdominal and pelvic), known as the "triple heater" or "San Jiao"
seven mortal forms in Daoism, representing carnal life and desires/contrasted with 三魂 three immortal souls

seven emotional states/seven affects of traditional Chinese medical theory and therapy, namely: joy 喜[xi3], anger 怒[nu4], anxiety 憂|忧[you1], thought 思[si1], grief 悲[bei1], fear 恐[kong3], fright 驚|惊[jing1]/seven relations
three immortal souls in Daoism, representing spirit and intellect
qi and blood (two basic bodily fluids of Chinese medicine)
